title: Stunning high-resolution images of disks swirling around 20 young stars outside of our solar system
text:
Astronomers have released stunning high-resolution images showing the disks of dust and gas swirling around 20 young stars outside of our solar system.

In a first of its kind survey, an international team used the Atacama Large Millimeter/ millimeter Array (ALMA) telescope in Chile for a large-sample investigation of these distant protoplanetary disks.

The study has revealed new insight on the potential abundance of Neptune- or Jupiter-sized young planets in other corners of the Milky Way, and suggests our solar system may not be entirely unique.

In a first of its kind survey, an international team used the Atacama Large Millimeter/ submillimetre Array (ALMA) telescope in Chile for a large-sample investigation of distant protoplanetary disks

Researchers at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas say the 20 nearby protoplanetary disks observed in the study suggest there may be a greater number of large, young planets in our galaxy that previously expected.

These have been left undetected due to the limitations of most planet-searching techniques used today.

But with ALMA, the team was able to image nearly two dozen protoplanetary disks, which could themselves contain young planets.

‘This implies that many extrasolar systems may be similar to our solar system in the sense that they also have Uranus and Neptune at the outer disk,’ says astrophysicist Zhaohuan Zhu.

‘In other words, our solar system could just be a regular planetary system in our Milky Way.’

Young planets eventually emerge from these protoplanetary disks surrounding stars.

According to the researchers, observing these processes in distant solar systems could shed light on Earth’s formation, too.

‘Understanding planet formation is related to understanding our origin,’ Zhu said.

Finding young planets in the disk, however, is a difficult task that the researchers liken to looking for a pebble in a pond.

‘It is very challenging,’ Zhu says.

‘But, when we drop the pebble into the pond, it will lead to ripples in the pond, which are more visible.

‘Similarly, when young planets are present in its water pond (the protoplanetary disk), it will excite waves too.

WHAT WILL HAPPEN TO EARTH WHEN THE SUN DIES? Five billion years from now, it's said the sun will have grown into a red giant star, more than a hundred times larger than its current size. Eventually, it will eject gas and dust to create an 'envelope' accounting for as much as half its mass. The core will become a tiny white dwarf star. This will shine for thousands of years, illuminating the envelope to create a ring-shaped planetary nebula. Five billion years from now, it's said the sun will have grown into a red giant star, more than a hundred times larger than its current size (file photo) While this metamorphosis will change the solar system, scientists are unsure what will happen to the third rock from the sun. We already know that our sun will be bigger and brighter, so that it will probably destroy any form of life on our planet. But whether the Earth's rocky core will survive is uncertain.

‘If the planet is massive enough, these waves become a tsunami and cause damages to the disk, forming a gap along the planet’s orbit in the disk.’

But, the researchers now have no shortage of data; the team analyzed a total of 540 images from the simulations to determine the correlation between the width of the gap and planet mass.

ALMA is able to spot the ripples and gaps in protoplanetary disks, hinting at the presence of an object.

The team then applied the relationships to their observations to weed out potential planets within.

According to graduate student Shangjia Zhang, ‘If these distant stars have young analogs of our Jupiter or Saturn, we have definitely caught them.’
